<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 302, 904, 316]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 384, 392, 399]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 221, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 880, 652]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.- Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity \((g)\) is needed, use \(10 \text{ms}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 681, 213, 695]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 697, 728, 727]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 50. The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[60, 0, 655, 230]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 242, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
Three coplanar forces of magnitudes \(P \mathrm{N}, 5 \mathrm{~N}\) and \(10 \mathrm{~N}\) act at a point \(O\), as shown in the diagram. The resultant of the three forces has magnitude \(Q \mathrm{N}\) and acts in a direction perpendicular to the force of magnitude \(P \mathrm{N}\).  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 304, 422, 321]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(P\) and the value of \(Q\).  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 305, 916, 321]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[60, 20, 415, 50]]<|/det|>
 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 72, 95, 84]]<|/det|>
3 

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 90, 822, 280]]<|/det|>
 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 297, 920, 362]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the velocity-time graph of the motion of a cyclist. The graph consists of three straight line segments. The cyclist passes a point \(O\) with speed \(3 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\) and then accelerates for \(10 \mathrm{~s}\) with constant acceleration \(0.5 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\). He then travels at constant speed for \(30 \mathrm{~s}\) before decelerating, coming to rest at point \(P\), covering a distance of \(80 \mathrm{~m}\) whilst decelerating. 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 376, 136, 388]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 376, 574, 392]]<|/det|>
Find the total time taken for the journey from \(O\) to \(P\). 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[885, 376, 920, 392]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3] 

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 412, 920, 920]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 136, 88]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
On the given axes, sketch a displacement-time graph for the cyclist's journey from \(O\) to \(P\), showing on your graph the distances travelled after 10 s and 40 s. [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 70, 101, 86]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 70, 587, 86]]<|/det|>
A lorry of mass 18 000 kg is travelling along a straight road.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 104, 136, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 104, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
On a horizontal section of the road, the power of the lorry's engine is constant. There is a constant resistance to motion of 1600 N.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 150, 184, 166]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 150, 918, 183]]<|/det|>
The steady speed which the lorry can maintain with the engine working at power \(P \mathrm{~W}\) is \(30 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 195, 351, 211]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 195, 916, 211]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 409, 184, 425]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 409, 918, 425]]<|/det|>
At an instant when the speed of the lorry is \(16 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\), its engine is working at a power of \(40 \mathrm{kW}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 437, 530, 453]]<|/det|>
Find the acceleration of the lorry at this instant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 437, 916, 453]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 651, 136, 667]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 651, 918, 699]]<|/det|>
When the lorry has reached a speed of \(20 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\), it begins to ascend a section of road inclined at an angle \(\alpha^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The engine now works at a power of 120 kW. There is no change in the lorry's speed as it ascends the hill. The constant resistance to motion remains 1600 N.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 711, 313, 727]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\alpha\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 711, 916, 727]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[0, 0, 12, 0]]<|/det|>
<pre>© UCLES 2025

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 945, 544, 956]]<|/det|>
<mark>9709/41/M/J/25

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[975, 945, 988, 956]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[283, 945, 315, 968]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 75, 101, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[120, 75, 911, 91]]<|/det|>
When a particle \(P\) of mass \(m \mathrm{~kg}\) has speed \(u \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\), its momentum is \(4 \mathrm{~N} \mathrm{~s}\) and its kinetic energy is \(16 \mathrm{~J}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 107, 136, 124]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 107, 459, 124]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(m\) and the value of \(u\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 107, 916, 124]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 388, 920, 437]]<|/det|>
<pre>\(P\) is now projected on a smooth horizontal surface with speed \(v \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\) directly towards a particle \(Q\) of mass \(1.25 \mathrm{~kg}\) which is stationary. After \(P\) and \(Q\) collide, the velocity of \(P\) is \(w \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\) and the velocity of \(Q\) is \(2 w \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\). The loss of kinetic energy in the collision is 25 J.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 452, 136, 468]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 452, 459, 468]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(v\) and the value of \(w\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 452, 916, 468]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[202, 85, 795, 216]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 234, 919, 330]]<|/det|>
Two particles, \(P\) and \(Q\), of masses \(0.3 \mathrm{~kg}\) and \(0.6 \mathrm{~kg}\) respectively, are attached to the ends of a light inextensible string. The string passes over a smooth pulley fixed at a point \(B\) where the inclined planes \(A B\) and \(B C\) meet. \(P\) lies on the smooth plane \(A B\) which is inclined at an angle \(\theta^{\circ}\) to the horizontal where \(\sin \theta^{\circ}=0.4\). \(Q\) lies on the plane \(B C\) which is inclined at \(30^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The string is taut and the particles can move on lines of greatest slope of the two planes (see diagram). The particles are released from rest.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 344, 460, 360]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 374, 585, 390]]<|/det|>
Find the tension in the string and the acceleration of \(Q\).  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 374, 916, 390]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 30, 415, 65]]<|/det|>
 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 136, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
It is given instead that the plane \(B C\) is rough. The work done against the frictional force when \(Q\) moves 2 m down the plane is 1.8 J. You should assume that \(P\) does **not** reach the pulley and that \(Q\) does **not** reach \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 131, 885, 148]]<|/det|>
Use an energy method to find the speed of \(Q\) when it has moved 2 m down the plane. 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[840, 131, 866, 148]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<pre>A second particle \(Y\) moves along another straight track, starting from a point \(P\) at time \(t=0\). The acceleration of \(Y\) at time \(t \mathrm{s}\) is \(a \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{-2}\), where \(a=0.8-0.6 t\). The velocity of \(Y\) when it leaves \(P\) is \(7.5 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 136, 136, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 136, 916, 168]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 73, 567, 88]]<|/det|>
# Additional page  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 102, 917, 134]]<|/det|>
If you use the following page to complete the answer to any question, the question number must be clearly shown.
